cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to key terms and concepts in media studies and provides an overview of theoretical and critical understandings of media. Students develop their understanding of the political, economic, social and cultural contexts in which mediated images and texts are produced, distributed, and consumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Media Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 1st and 2nd year students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys the history of media and communication from the development of writing through the printing press, newspaper, telegraph, radio, film, television and internet. Students examine the complex interplay among changing media technologies and cultural, political and social changes, from the rise of a public sphere to the development of highly-mediated forms of self identity.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 1st and 2nd year students. Any remaining spaces will open to 3rd year students on July 27th.

cmCourseInfo.description: What makes humans humans, animals animals, and machines machines? This course probes the leaky boundaries between these categories through an examination of various media drawn from science fiction, contemporary art, film, TV, and the critical work of media and posthumanist theorists on cyborgs, genetically-modified organisms, and other hybrid creatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human, Animal, Machine

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: What makes humans humans, animals animals, and machines machines? This course probes the leaky boundaries between these categories through an examination of various media drawn from science fiction, contemporary art, film, TV, and the critical work of media and posthumanist theorists on cyborgs, genetically-modified organisms, and other hybrid creatures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human, Animal, Machine

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the study of advertising as social communication and provides a historical perspective on advertising's role in the emergence and perpetuation of "consumer culture". The course examines the strategies employed to promote the circulation of goods as well as the impact of advertising on the creation of new habits and expectations in everyday life.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advertising and Consumer Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time/date/room change (20/06/23)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the role of technological and cultural networks in mediating and facilitating the social, economic, and political processes of globalization. Key themes include imperialism, militarization, global political economy, activism, and emerging media technologies. Particular attention is paid to cultures of media production and reception outside of North America. Same as GASB05H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Media and Globalization

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course considers technology as an everyday social practice. It challenges deterministic ideas of technology as a cause of social change and examines theories that understand technology and culture as mutually constituted. Perspectives include actor-network theory, critical theory of technology, feminist technology studies, media archaeology, and cyber-, post- and transhumanism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Technology, Culture and Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

courses.name: Social Media, Platform Politics and Digital Cultures

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on the technological, social, cultural, and political-economic organization of media and communication by critically engaging with social media, digital platforms, and apps. The dominance of platforms operated by Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon raises questions about platform politics and how platform owners engineer sociality and digital culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Media, Platform Politics and Digital Cultures

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course follows money in media industries. It introduces a variety of economic theories and methods to analyse cultural production and circulation, and the organization of media and communication companies. These approaches are used to better understand the political economy of digital platforms, apps, television, film, and games.
cmCourseInfo.title: Political Economy of Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the key terms and concepts in new media studies as well as approaches to new media criticism. Students examine the myriad ways that new media contribute to an ongoing reformulation of the dynamics of contemporary society, including changing concepts of community, communication, identity, privacy, property, and the political.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mapping New Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: Visual Culture studies the construction of the visual in art, media, technology and everyday life. Students learn the tools of visual analysis; investigate how visual depictions such as YouTube and advertising structure and convey ideologies; and study the institutional, economic, political, social, and market factors in the making of contemporary visual culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Visual Culture and Communication

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: Visual Culture studies the construction of the visual in art, media, technology and everyday life. Students learn the tools of visual analysis; investigate how visual depictions such as YouTube and advertising structure and convey ideologies; and study the institutional, economic, political, social, and market factors in the making of contemporary visual culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Visual Culture and Communication

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP
Initially restricted to 2nd and 3rd year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies. On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the importance of sound and sound technology to visual media practices by considering how visuality in cinema, video, television, gaming, and new media art is organized and supported by aural techniques such as music, voice, architecture, and sound effects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sound and Visual Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: RP

On Thursday, July 27th, any remaining spaces will open to 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies - Media Studies Stream, and Minor program in Media Studies.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time/date/room change (20/06/23)

cmCourseInfo.description: This is an advanced seminar for third and fourth year students on theories applied to the study of media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theories in Media Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the centrality of mass media such as television, film, the Web, and mobile media in the formation of multiple identities and the role of media as focal points for various cultural and political contestations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media, Identities and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the centrality of mass media such as television, film, the Web, and mobile media in the formation of multiple identities and the role of media as focal points for various cultural and political contestations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media, Identities and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), and Minor program in Media Studies.

You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: Anthropology studies language and media in ways that show the impact of cultural context. This course introduces this approach and also considers the role of language and media with respect to intersecting themes: ritual, religion, gender, race/ethnicity, power, nationalism, and globalization. Class assignments deal with lectures, readings, and students' examples. Same as ANTC59H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Language and Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on modern-day scandals, ranging from scandals of politicians, corporate CEOs, and celebrities to scandals involving ordinary people. It examines scandals as conditioned by technological, social, cultural, political, and economic forces and as a site where meanings of deviances of all sorts are negotiated and constructed. It also pays close attention to media and journalistic practices at the core of scandals.
cmCourseInfo.title: Understanding Scandals

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies program (both streams), Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies, and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies, 1.0 credit if you are in Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the complex and dynamic interplay of media and politics in contemporary China and the role of the government in this process. Same as GASC40H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Media and Politics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies program (both streams), Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies, and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies, 1.0 credit if you are in Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

courses.name: Media and Popular Culture in East Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to media industries and commercial popular cultural forms in East Asia. Topics include reality TV, TV dramas, anime and manga, as well as issues such as regional cultural flows, global impact of Asian popular culture, and the localization of global media in East Asia. Same as GASC41H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Media and Popular Culture in East Asia

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies program (both streams), Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies, and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies, 1.0 credit if you are in Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: New media technologies enable more production and distribution of culturally, ethnically and linguistically diverse voices than ever before. Who produces these diverse voices and how accessible are these media? This course explores various types of diasporic media from century-old newspapers to young and hip news and magazine blogs, produced by and for members of a multicultural society. Same as JOUC60H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Diasporic Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses] or [2.0 credits at the B-level in JOU courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies, 1.0 credit if you are in Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to ethical issues in media. Students learn theoretical aspects of ethics and apply them to media industries and practices in the context of advertising, public relations, journalism, mass media entertainment, and online culture. Same as JOUC63H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Ethics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies program (both streams), Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies, and Minor program in Media Studies.

You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: Media are central to organizing cultural discourse about technology and the future. This course examines how the popularization of both real and imagined technologies in various media forms contribute to cultural attitudes that attend the introduction and social diffusion of new technologies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media and Technology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media Studies, the Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies, and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies, 1.0 credit if you are in Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to academic perspectives on games and play. Students develop a critical understanding of a variety of topics and discussions related to games, gamification, and play in the physical and virtual world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Games and Play
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (both streams), and Minor program in Media Studies.

You may only complete 2.0 MDSC-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies, and 1.5 credits if you are in a Minor program in Media Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

cmCourseInfo.description: Selfies are an integral component of contemporary media culture and used to sell everyone from niche celebrities to the Prime Minister. This class examines the many meanings of selfies to trace their importance in contemporary media and digital cultures as well as their place within, and relationship to, historically and theoretically grounded concepts of photography and self portraiture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Selfies and the Selfie Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses] or [2.0 credits at the B-level in JOU courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDSC-levels beyond this limit.

courses.name: Senior Seminar: Topics in Media and Arts

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a senior seminar that focuses on the connections among media and the arts. Students explore how artists use the potentials offered by various media forms, including digital media, to create new ways of expression. Topics vary.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Media and Arts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 3.0 credits in MDS courses, including 1.0 credit at the C-level

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: R
Restricted to 4th year students in Major program in Media Studies, Major program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies Program (Media Stream Only).

You may only complete 0.5 MDS D-level credits if you are in a Major program in Media Studies, Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Studies. You will be automatically refused from enrollment in any MDS D-levels beyond this limit.


Attendance in this course is of utmost importance starting Week 1. Students who have not attended Week 1, and Week 2 classes and have not have not been in contact with your Instructor about your absence, will be removed by Friday, September 15th.

courses.name: Senior Seminar: Topics in Media and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a senior seminar that focuses on media and society. It explores the social and political implications of media, including digital media, and how social forces shape their development. Topics vary.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Media and Society
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 3.0 credits in MDS courses, including 1.0 credit at the C-level
